senses.sense_definition: An elected official in Ancient Rome responsible for protecting the interests and rights of the common people.

examples.text: The <w>tribune</w> used his veto power to stop the unjust law from passing.
In history class, we learned how a <w>tribune</w> of the plebs could challenge the authority of the consuls.

senses.sense_definition: A raised platform or place where a speaker stands to address an assembly; also, a medium or opportunity to express opinions.

examples.text: The president mounted the <w>tribune</w> to deliver his inaugural address to the nation.
This newspaper serves as a <w>tribune</w> for citizens to voice their concerns about local government.

senses.sense_definition: A person who upholds and defends the rights of the people, often as an eloquent public speaker.

examples.text: He was regarded as a <w>tribune</w> of the people, tirelessly fighting for social justice.
The senator acted as a <w>tribune</w> for the working class during the economic crisis.

senses.sense_definition: A high-ranking military officer in the legions of Ancient Rome.

examples.text: The military <w>tribune</w> commanded the cohort to hold their position against the enemy.
He served as a <w>tribune</w> in the army before entering political life in Rome.

senses.sense_definition: A semicircular or polygonal apse in a church, or a raised gallery overlooking the nave.

examples.text: The choir gathered in the <w>tribune</w> to sing during the cathedral service.
Architects admired the vaulted ceiling of the <w>tribune</w> at the end of the basilica.

senses.sense_definition: A place name used for several towns and communities in North America.

examples.text: They stopped for gas in the small town of <w>Tribune</w> while driving through Kansas.
My grandparents live in a quiet community called <w>Tribune</w>.
